doc.title: Weekend Consumer Blast: Authentic Labubu or counterfeit Lafufu? Your guide to identification & enforcement actions
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-29/Weekend Consumer Blast Authentic Labubu or counterfeit Lafufu Your guide to identification enforcement actionsWeekend Co_2025-08-29

passages.text: By Melinda Hu, Ran Yang and Ethan Xu- China Consumer

Meet Labubu, the elfin troublemaker who's gone from obscure picture book character to the must- have accessory. Created by Hong Kong artist Kasing Lung for "The Story of Puca," these impish creatures lived in relative obscurity until April 2024, when BLACKPINK's Lisa casually shared her Labubu collection on social media. The ensuing frenzy evokes memories of past collector manias, but amplified by the viral modern social media. Suddenly everyone from Rihanna to David Bedham was flaunting their Labubus. With skyrocketing demand, it was only a matter of time before the fakers entered the chat. Enter the "Lafufu"—the counterfeit cousin threatening the integrity of the collection. In this blast, we delve into the subtle art of Labubu authentication, where discerning collectors can arm themselves against an increasingly sophisticated market of imitations.
EXHIBIT 1: Labubu - Exciting Macaron series
Source: Pop Mart, Bernstein analysis
EXHIBIT 2: Blackpink's Lisa with Labubu
Source: Youtube, Bernstein analysis

The well- developed toy supply chain in China has, to some extent, contributed to the rise of Lafufu. As the world's largest toy producer, China accounts for \(\sim 70\% - 80\%\) of global toy production, with over 7,000 manufacturers, according to China IRN. Dongguan, a major manufacturing hub with more than 4,000 toy enterprises, plays a pivotal role in the Labubu supply chain. Although factories producing Labubu are bound by confidentiality agreements, many external
factories are eager to capitalize on the Labubu boom by producing Lafufus. These manufacturers operate discreetly, permitting only large-order clients to visit their production sites.

A widespread distribution network has been established for Lafufus. In China, consumers can easily purchase Lafufu through e- commerce platforms such as Douyin and Taobao, as well as social media like Red Note. Labubu fans can also find Lafufu in wholesale markets like Huaqiangbei (an area in Shenzhen famous for cheap 3C products) and offline stores everywhere. Internationally, Lafufu are entering the US, Europe, and Southeast Asia through wholesale distributors and smugglers. E- commerce platforms like Amazon and AliExpress, along with independent websites, remain key distribution channels. Some consumers even reported finding Lafufus in 7- Eleven stores in the U.S. (Link)

Bought the ridiculous lafufu on AliExpress (can you believe it sold

The eldest child at home wanted a labubu, and after much effort, I managed to buy him two authentic ones. While waiting for the delivery, he wanted to get two lafufu to play with, so I spent \$15 on alexpress to buy two. Upon receiving the goods, it turned out... no surprise, only shock it's... just absurd to the extent of
What's even more absurd is that I listed them on Facebook for \$20, and as soon as the ad went up, several people inquired. Within ten minutes,
Source: Red Note, Bernstein analysis
There are three types of Lafufu available in the market:
1. Low-End Counterfeit: Poor-quality replicas easily identified as fakes, typically priced between RMB 30-69.
2. High-End Replica: These closely resemble genuine Labubu toys, sometimes featuring QR codes but might link to counterfeit websites. Prices range from RMB 200-500, depending on quality.

3. Modified Version: Manufacturers alter the original Labubu design and market it as a "modified version," which may include additional features like lights or sounds, or have colors and sizes that Labubu does not originally have. Prices are often close to those of authentic Labubu.
Source: Red Note, Bernstein analysis

While low- end counterfeits and modified versions are relatively easy to spot, high- end replicas can be more challenging to distinguish (Exhibit 16). We summarized other tips for identifying Lafufu vs. Labubu:

1. Count the Teeth: Authentic Labubus has exactly nine sharp, triangular fangs, with clear gaps between each tooth and neatly painted along the blue line of the mouth. Counterfeits may have more or fewer teeth (e.g., 8 or 10), poorly painted teeth with noticeable gaps or paint blobs, or teeth that appear fused without distinct spacing. (Exhibit 9)

2. Logo on Foot: Genuine Labubus have a clear, sharp Pop Mart logo embossed or printed on the bottom of the left foot, centered and free of misspellings. Newer models (from 2024 onward) also have a UV-reactive stamp on the right foot. Fakes often lack these stamps, have blurry or misaligned logos, or display UV icons visible to the naked eye, typically in incorrect poses like a sitting figure for a standing series. (Exhibit 10)

3. Desiccant: Authentic Labubus come with a desiccant packet featuring a clear, dark Pop Mart logo in high-quality print. Counterfeit packets may have blurry, low-quality printing or lack the logo. Some fakes may omit the desiccant altogether, which is a red flag. (Exhibit 11)
4. Identity Card: Genuine Labubus include a premium-feeling identity card in pastel tones with sharp, clear logos, while fakes often have blurry prints or no card at all. (Exhibit 12)

5. QR Code Scan: Most newer Labubu models include a QR code on a holographic Pop Mart sticker on the box or a fabric/paper tag, which should redirect to Pop Mart's official verification site when scanned. Enter the four-digit code (often found under scratch-off Chinese text beneath the QR code) to confirm authenticity. Counterfeit QR codes may lead to unrelated or suspicious websites, redirect through intermediary domains, or fail to scan properly due to blurry printing. Note that older Labubu models (pre-2023) may lack QR codes, so rely on other physical checks for those. (Exhibit 13)
6. Packaging: Genuine Labubu boxes have a matte finish, smooth texture, and muted pastel colors with sharp, embossed printing. Fakes often feature glossy, vibrant, or uneven surfaces,
misspelled logos (e.g., "Popm Mart"), or flat- looking holographic stickers. (Exhibit 14)

7. Features: Generally, Lafufu displays lower quality and lacks detailed features of Labubu. Authentic Labubus have soft, fluffy fur, seamless stitching, and a pale, peachy face with a matte finish and subtle blush. Fakes may use coarse materials, visible stitching, overly vibrant face colors (e.g., pink or orange), or dull, flat eyes. (Exhibit 15)
EXHIBIT 8: The difference between Labubu and Lafufu

PackagingBox Texture and LogoMatte surface with a subtle texture and feature an embossed logoOften have a glossy, paper-like, or plastic-like surface without embossingAnti-Counterfeit measureUrboring DesignOne-time destructive unboxing design and cannot be restored once openedCan often be reopened and closedLabelHave a holographic label on the blind box with a clear double “P” shimmerMay lack this label or have a low-quality hologramItems and DocumentationIdentity CardHave high-quality printing and materialsMay link to a fake verification pagePhysical FeaturesDesiccantSmall rectangular packets with a clear, dark logoCards are often thin, with inconsistent paper quality (either rough or glossy), and dull or gray colorsTeethHave nine teeth which are stress-especially modeled and slightly uneven in size and shape, with a total dented with white colorOften have blurry printing, faded patterns, or even no desiccant at allMaterial and StitchingUse fine fur material with even and neat stitchingOften have the wrong number of teeth (7-10), which may be painted on rather than modeled, and are either an untraceable or a fake one often use inferior fur with uneven stitching or exposed threadsBaseHave a clear brand logoOften don't have brand logosOften don't have brand logos
Source: Bernstein analysis
EXHIBIT 9: Identifying Labubu vs Lafufu: Labubu has nine teethEXHIBIT 10: Identifying Labubu vs Lafufu: There's a clear brand logo on Labubu's foot
Source: Red Note, Bernstein analysis

Source: Red Note, Bernstein analysis
Source: Red Note, Bernstein analysis
EXHIBIT 13: Consumers can scan the QR code for quick verification
Source: Red Note, Bernstein analysis
EXHIBIT 15: Authentic Labubus have peachy face with a matte finish and subtle blush
Source: Red Note, Bernstein
China Customs is actively protecting Labubu's intellectual property rights. In 2025, they seized 1.83 million counterfeit Labubu products (Link) and regularly post on their official WeChat
EXHIBIT 14: Genuine Labubu boxes have a matte finish, smooth texture, and muted pastel colors with sharp, embossed printing
Source: Red Note, Bernstein analysis
EXHIBIT 16: The verification report on Qiandao App
Source: Red Note, Bernstein analysis
account to raise public awareness, encouraging consumers to purchase only authentic items. Through these efforts, they aim to promote intellectual property respect and support legitimate brands.

In June, China Customs' official WeChat account featured Lafutu for 17 consecutive days, gaining over 110,000 new followers. Each post included a humorous headline, such as "Every day I'm immersed in catching Lafutu and can't extricate myself" and "Does customs release 'bu' (cloth)? No, customs doesn't release cloth, customs checks for fake Bubs." These creative communications have attracted significant public attention.
Through these representative cases, China Customs aims to emphasize three key points:

1. Daigou (personal shoppers who purchase goods on others' behalf) must declare their activities and pay appropriate taxes. 
2. Combating counterfeit goods is a core custom responsibility, many didn't realize customs also handles intellectual property violations. 
3. Their anti-counterfeiting work serves a greater purpose: protecting intellectual property, fostering innovation, and supporting Chinese manufacturing brands.
Source: Wechat Official Account

The Bernstein brand rates stocks based on forecasts of relative performance for the next 12 months versus the S&P 500 for stocks listed on the U.S. and Canadian exchanges, versus the Bloomberg Europe Developed Markets Large and Mid Cap Price Return Index (EDM) for stocks listed on the European exchanges and emerging markets exchanges outside of the Asia Pacific region, versus the Bloomberg Japan Large and Mid Cap Price Return Index USD (JP) for stocks listed on the Japanese exchanges, and versus the Bloomberg Asia ex- Japan Large and Mid Cap Price Return Index (ASIAX) for stocks listed on the Asian (ex- Japan) exchanges - unless otherwise specified.
The Bernstein brand has three categories of ratings:

- Outperform: Stock will outpace the market index by more than 15 pp- Market-Perform: Stock will perform in line with the market index to within +/-15 pp- Underperform: Stock will trail the performance of the market index by more than 15 pp

Coverage Suspended: Coverage of a company under the Bernstein research brand has been suspended. Ratings and price targets are suspended temporarily, are no longer current, and should therefore not be relied upon.

Not Rated: A rating assigned when the stock cannot be accurately valued, or the performance of the company accurately predicted, at the present time. The covering analyst may continue to publish research reports on the company to update investors on events and developments.
Not Covered (NC) denotes companies that are not under coverage.

The Autonomous brand rates stocks as indicated below. As our benchmarks we use the Bloomberg Europe 500 Banks And Financial Services Index (BEBANKS) and Bloomberg Europe Dev Mkt Financials Large and Mid Cap Price Ret Index EUR (EDMFI) index for developed European banks and Payments, the Bloomberg Europe 500 Insurance Index (BEINSUR) for European insurers, the S&P 500 and S&P Financials for US banks and Payments coverage, S5LIFE for US Insurance, the S&P Insurance Select Industry (SPSIINS) for US Non-Life Insurers coverage, and the Bloomberg Emerging Markets Financials Large, Mid and Small Cap Price Return Index (EMLSF) for emerging market banks and insurers and Payments. Ratings are stated relative to the sector (not the market).
The Autonomous brand has three categories of ratings:

Outperform (OP): Stock will outpace the relevant index by more than 10 pp- Neutral (N): Stock will perform in line with the market index to within \(+ / - 10\) pp- Underperform (UP): Stock will trail the performance of the relevant index by more than 10 pp

Coverage Suspended: Coverage of a company under the Bernstein research brand has been suspended. Ratings and price targets are suspended temporarily, are no longer current, and should therefore not be relied upon.

Not Rated: A rating assigned when the stock cannot be accurately valued, or the performance of the company accurately predicted, at the present time. The covering analyst may continue to publish research reports on the company to update investors on events and developments.
Those denoted as 'Feature' (e.g., Feature Outperform FOP, Feature Under Outperform FUP) are our core ideas. Not Covered (NC) denotes companies that are not under coverage.
For both brands, recommendations are based on a 12- month time horizon.
